body:
Unsurprisingly, I also have a few Linux instances behind that same IP that report:
` WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header`

I don't usually notice those since they are headless instances.

The limit is 60 requests per hour for unauthenticated access. This shouldn't be a problem when using just Syncthing (unless you've got 60+ devices that all check for updates at the same time…). Do you (or anyone else under the same IP address) use other software that also utilises the GitHub API?

Curl request from a host behind that IP address.  Looking at the x- headers the rate limit appears to be 60 requests per interval and the x-ratelimit-reset timestamp should be respected.

```
curl -i 'https://api.github.com/repos/syncthing/syncthing/releases/assets/120749509'

HTTP/2 403
date: Wed, 09 Aug 2023 15:15:49 GMT
server: Varnish
strict-transport-security: max-age=31536000; includeSubdomains; preload
x-content-type-options: nosniff
x-frame-options: deny
x-xss-protection: 1; mode=block
content-security-policy: default-src 'none'; style-src 'unsafe-inline'
access-control-allow-origin: *
access-control-expose-headers: ETag, Link, Location, Retry-After, X-GitHub-OTP, X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset, X-RateLimit-Used, X-RateLimit-Resource, X-OAuth-Scopes, X-Accepted-OAuth-Scopes, X-Poll-Interval, X-GitHub-Media-Type, Deprecation, Sunset
content-type: application/json; charset=utf-8
referrer-policy: origin-when-cross-origin, strict-origin-when-cross-origin
x-github-media-type: github.v3; format=json
x-ratelimit-limit: 60
x-ratelimit-remaining: 0
x-ratelimit-reset: 1691595851
x-ratelimit-resource: core
x-ratelimit-used: 60
content-length: 279
x-github-request-id: 8626:43F9:2F48691:5FF0540:64D3ADA4

{"message":"API rate limit exceeded for 24.243.x.x. (But here's the good news: Authenticated requests get a higher rate limit. Check out the documentation for more details.)","documentation_url":"https://docs.github.com/rest/overview/resources-in-the-rest-api#rate-limiting"}
```

> The limit is 60 requests per hour for unauthenticated access. This shouldn't be a problem when using just Syncthing (unless you've got 60+ devices that all check for updates at the same time…). Do you (or anyone else under the same IP address) use other software that also utilises the GitHub API?

I have 7 instances total behind that IP and it appears that syncthing is making a request to api.github.com every time it connects to a peer and that peer reports a later version than the local version which quickly burns through that 60 limit.

I am also a pretend software developer by trade so it is entirely possible that other things running on my home network besides syncthing are trying to utilize the Github API as a makeshift CDN and are contributing to that.  However, syncthing is the only thing I am currently aware of that is having a problem.

Regardless, it appears that syncthing both misinterprets the rate limit response as a valid response and does not respect the x-ratelimit-reset header.
If I spent some time to work up a PR that makes syncthing pay attention to the http response code and honor the x-ratelimit headers would it be accepted?

Some more information, this is the log (irrelevant entries removed) from a single instance of syncthing v1.23.6 running on a linux host that was repeatedly attempting to update in response to remote peers reporting they were on the newer v1.23.7 version:

```
Aug 09 06:13:32 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:13:32 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
Aug 09 06:13:35 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:13:35 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
Aug 09 06:14:43 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:14:43 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
Aug 09 06:14:46 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:14:46 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
Aug 09 06:18:43 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:18:43 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
Aug 09 06:20:56 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:20:56 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
Aug 09 06:21:17 nebula rc.local[1078]: [DXNJM] 2023/08/09 06:21:17 WARNING: Automatic upgrade: gzip: invalid header
```

To be clear, this is not the upgrade check, it's the actual upgrade download. The upgrade check, which happens somewhat frequently (for example every time a newer machine connects to us) goes to upgrades.syncthing.net which is our own server, with caching, entirely sidestepping the github API limits.

However, when an upgrade is deemed possible and necessary the asset is downloaded from the GitHub release, which is what happens here (and gets rejected). I suspect think that's a fairly unusual situation, as it is literally one "API request" (actually zip/tar.gz download) per released version.

Even with your cluster of five machines, Syncthing would normally cause _five_ such API requests, in total, per month. But if they fail, they will of course be retried at some point. So, I don't think it's fair to say we trigger the limit in question. Things will however fail to work if you're already over it.
Is Githubs container registry subject to the same ratelimit?
Actually, I may have a lead on another culprit - was looking for traffic sent to 140.82.114.3 when I really needed to be looking at 140.82/16.

Alright, for future generations that come after me.  I have a Raspberry Pi that I send to people to help diagnose network issues remotely so they can hold their ISPs accountable.  Part of the software stack running on it includes telegraf which is configured to collect tcp/icmp response telemetry against a variety of public and semi-public remote hosts.

One of those public hosts happens to be `api.github.com` and it appears that even a simple HEAD request to https://api.github.com/ counts against the hourly quota now.  So - I think it is safe to say that syncthing was (mostly) an innocent bystander but it does contribute to the problem slightly by accessing assets hosted on GH via the api.

So, while technically not-a-bug - I think syncthing's behavior could be improved by:

1) paying attention to http status codes when fetching remote resources and logging a meaningful error message on failure
2) if a rate limit response is returned, honor the x-ratelimit-rest header instead of continuing to make requests and log the message so it is clear to the user what is happening

Potential feature request?  Should I go post this in the forum?
1) Provide a mechanism for configuring and using personal GH tokens to fetch GH resources since they have a much more generous rate limit

If nothing else - a FAQ entry would be nice.
The status should be properly logged. But i think the retry-after handling is a bit of an overkill here.

I won't pretend to have fully internalized syncthing's code base at this point but is it really overkill to have a map with a host and retry-after entry in it to check before making the http call?  I would think that honoring the remote host's request that the client wait to retry the call is being a good netizen but maybe my scenario was enough of a corner case that it isn't worth the effort.

I think this can be resolved more simply by resolving the URL used one step further, IIRC the url seem above mostly results in a redirect, which we could do already in the upgrade server before serving the response.

rename.from: Github API rate limit being triggered by automatic upgrades
rename.to: Github API rate limit response preventing automatic upgrades

body: There, no requests towards the api.github.com domain. I think that should solve it.
Indeed.  Thanks for all the effort you and everyone else put into this project.
